channel.title: English
channel.description:
When someone says [b]the sixteenth January[/b], would you take it as the sixteenth of January(Which is correct) or the sixteenth January(In a year)(Which is wrong)? Some idiotic person in my class insists that its correct? Help?
Please provide some reason why it is wrong to you, thank you.

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @I_Br3ndan_I I Br3ndan I
item.description:
@I_Br3ndan_I wrote:

She’s just being a wide bastard tbh. It doesn’t really matter, even the exam markers won’t give a ****.

Read full topic

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @curtinman curtinman
item.description:
@curtinman wrote:

well i think it means 16 years cause say the world begins and its 16/1 wouldnt that be the 16th january?

Read full topic

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @USMC USMC
item.description:
@USMC wrote:

In America, dates are pronouced without the “of” as we do in the UK.

Thefore if i said “February 13th”, that would be “The 13th of February”.

got it?

Read full topic

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @Tenacious_T Tenacious T
item.description:
@Tenacious_T wrote:

why not just say January 16th? i mean 16th of January would be right yes, but if he thought that you were wrong about that then he would prob. say January the 16th…

Read full topic

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @bobby Bobby
item.description:
@bobby wrote:

[quote=“Mr.Chris, post:10, topic:159248”]EU go by date/month/year as David pointed out.

You need the ‘of’ after the sixteenth because without it, it would mean that the sixteenth January as in 16 Januaries in 16 years.

When I write a date I write ‘16th January 07’. I automatically think 16th OF January, however, I don’t write ‘Of’. 99% of people probably don’t write of. Only fools would think it meant the sixteenth January in 16 years.[/quote]

oh i misread. so i was right.

Read full topic

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @Shadower Shadower
item.description:
@Shadower wrote:

Actually, it’s whether it’s correct or wrong, because this stupid classmate of mine is nitpicking on small things like this, so I’m giving her a taste of her own medicine. I know its 16th of Jan, but I said already, she wants to nitpick so I’ll nitpick.

Read full topic

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @Mr.Chris Mr.Chris
item.description:
@Mr.Chris wrote:

EU go by date/month/year as David pointed out.

Eh Pretty Easy:

You need the ‘of’ after the sixteenth because without it, it would mean that the sixteenth January as in 16 Januaries in 16 years.

When I write a date I write ‘16th January 07’. I automatically think 16th OF January, however, I don’t write ‘Of’. 99% of people probably don’t write of. Only fools would think it meant the sixteenth January in 16 years.

Read full topic

we say 1/10/07 is january 10th doesn’t europe say 10/1/07 mean ing janaury 10th?
[/quote]
I’ve always known it to be DD/MM/YY and i live in the UK =D

shadower your friend is probably just being a stubborn ass hole.[/quote]oh my spanish teacher says its differnt in europe. maybe its just spain or something

"... duh there is only ONE sixteenth january. which is why i put THE sixteenth jan. if i had put A sixteenth jan then i would be truly making a mistake"

item.title: English
item.dc:creator: @dragonus18 dragonus18
item.description:
@dragonus18 wrote:

because the 16th January would be the 16th month of January which would be the beginning of the 16th year. the 16th OF January would symbolize the 16th day in January instead of the 16th year.

Read full topic

When someone says the sixteenth January, would you take it as the sixteenth of January(Which is correct) or the sixteenth January(In a year)(Which is wrong)? Some idiotic person in my class insists that its correct? Help?
